title: Guru Nanak Jayanti
short_description: Gurpurab celebrates the birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Dev Ji with prayers, processions, and community kitchens.
long_description:
Guru Nanak Jayanti, also known as Gurpurab, marks the birth of the first Sikh Guru and the founder of Sikhism, Guru Nanak Dev Ji. It is one of the most sacred festivals in Sikhism. The celebrations begin two days earlier with the 'Akhand Path', a 48-hour non-stop reading of the Guru Granth Sahib (holy book). 

One day before Gurpurab, a massive procession called 'Nagar Kirtan' is organized, led by the 'Panj Pyaras' (Five Beloved Ones) holding the Sikh flag. The streets resound with the singing of hymns and display of martial arts (Gatka). On the day of the festival, Gurdwaras (Sikh temples) are beautifully illuminated. The spirit of 'Seva' (service) is paramount; volunteers prepare and serve 'Langar' (community meal) to everyone, regardless of caste or religion, symbolizing equality.
significance: Celebrates the birth and teachings of Guru Nanak Dev Ji, emphasizing oneness of God and equality.
key_rituals: Akhand Path: 48-hour continuous reading of the holy book.
Nagar Kirtan: A grand religious procession through the city.
Langar: Preparation and serving of free community meals.
Gatka: Demonstration of traditional Sikh martial arts.

top_places.best_to_experience: The ethereal illumination of the temple and the massive fireworks display.

top_places.best_to_experience: Pilgrimage (requires visa) to the Janam Asthan Gurdwara.

top_places.title: Delhi
top_places.best_to_experience: Gurdwara Bangla Sahib and Sis Ganj Sahib processions.

practical_info.dress_tips: It is mandatory to cover your head in Gurdwaras (headscarves are usually provided). Dress modestly.
practical_info.safety_tips: Very safe, family-oriented atmosphere. Overcrowding is the only concern.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Most major Gurdwaras are wheelchair accessible.

faqs.q: Can anyone eat at the Langar?
faqs.a: Yes, absolutely everyone is welcome to sit on the floor and eat the vegetarian meal.
Allowed in the complex, but usually not inside the inner sanctum where the book is kept.
